title: New Mexico Unveils Plan to Offer Free College Tuition
text:
New Mexico’s Democratic Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham on Wednesday unveiled an ambitious new plan that would provide free college tuition to all in-state students.

The plan would apply to students regardless of the family’s income level, a departure from similar plans in other states, which are geared toward low-income students. New Mexico’s plan would apply to students at two and four-year colleges regardless of their immigration status.

Ms. Grisham called the program “an absolute game-changer” for the state.

Join the conversation below. “Higher education in this state, a victim of the recession, has been starved in recent years. We are pivoting to a robust reinvestment in higher learning—specifically and directly in our students,” Ms. Grisham said at the 2019 New Mexico Higher Education Summit, where she made the announcement. If passed, the plan, which is called New Mexico Opportunity Scholarship, would affect an estimated 55,000 students across the state’s 29 public higher-education institutions. The plan would also apply to adults returning to school. Although Democrats control both houses of the state’s legislature, it is unclear if the plan will pass. State Sen. Gregg Fulfer, a Republican, believes the state needs to “fix what’s broke” before creating new plans that require new sources of money that have to be sustained over time. “I think with the education crisis we are in, this will be hard to pass in the legislative session coming and therefore will need to be looked at closely,” Mr. Fulfer said. Tripp Stelnicki, the governor’s director of communications, said he was optimistic the plan would be approved. New Mexico State Sen. Antoinette Sedillo Lopez said the new plan would help create a much needed skilled workforce and address poverty and other social issues in the state. “It is not a done deal, but I know it will be very seriously considered by legislators,” Ms. Lopez said. If the legislature passes the plan, New Mexico would join 20 states that have similar programs, including New York’s Excelsior Scholarship, which provides free tuition to students attending state colleges for families making up to $125,000.
